title: 114_hr2324
content: The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" allows for special conveyance authority regarding small parcels of national forest system land and public lands. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines terms like adjacent landholder, Director concerned, and eligible Federal lands parcel, which includes National Forest System land or public lands sharing boundaries with non-Federal land. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines an eligible Federal lands parcel as National Forest System land or public lands that share boundaries with non-Federal land, are located in areas with a population of at least 500 residents, do not have existing rights held by non-Federal entities, do not contain exceptional resources, and are not habitat for endangered species. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines an eligible Federal lands parcel as National Forest System land or public lands that share boundaries with non-Federal land, are located in areas with a population of at least 500 residents, do not have existing rights held by non-Federal entities, and are not habitat for endangered species. An "exceptional resource" is a resource of scientific, historic, cultural, or recreational value on public lands that requires extraordinary conservation and protection for the benefit of the public. The term "National Forest System land" refers to land within the National Forest System, including National Grasslands and land utilization projects designated as National Grasslands. The term "Indian tribe" is defined as per the Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act of 1994. The term "National Forest System land" includes National Grasslands and land utilization projects designated as National Grasslands, but excludes land managed by the Forest Service in certain designated areas. The term "public lands" refers to various designated areas such as national conservation areas, riparian conservation areas, recreation areas, scenic areas, natural landmarks, wilderness areas, and more, excluding Bureau of Land Management-managed lands. The term "public lands" excludes Bureau of Land Management-managed lands and includes various designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, and national scenic areas. The term "public lands" excludes Bureau of Land Management-managed lands and includes designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, national scenic areas, and other protected areas. The Regional Forester concerned selects eligible Federal lands parcels for conveyance in response to requests from adjacent landholders. The Forest Service Region selects eligible Federal lands parcels for conveyance either in response to requests from adjacent landholders or upon recommendation from the Bureau of Land Management or National Forest System. Adjacent landholders can request to purchase a parcel through a process created by the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior. The Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior have created a process for adjacent landholders to request to purchase eligible Federal lands parcels. The process is open to the public, available online, and consistent with other public purchase request processes used by the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management. The Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior have established a process for adjacent landholders to request the purchase of eligible Federal lands parcels. The process is public, online, and must be available within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. When a request is submitted, the Director or Regional Forester will review the parcel within 30 days to determine eligibility for conveyance. The Director or Regional Forester will review a parcel of National Forest System land or public lands within 30 days of receiving a request to determine if it meets the criteria for conveyance. If the parcel does not qualify, the landowner will be provided with a written explanation for the rejection. If a landowner's request for conveyance of National Forest System land or public lands fails to meet the criteria, the Director or Regional Forester will provide a written explanation detailing the reasons for rejection, including how the parcel does not satisfy the eligibility requirements and the potential impact of continued federal administration on the parcel and surrounding economy. The conveyance of Federal lands parcel must meet eligibility requirements, with a limit of 160 acres unless approved for additional acreage by the Director or Regional Forester. An appeal process is available for rejected requests. An eligible Federal lands parcel conveyed under this section may not exceed 160 acres unless approved for additional acreage by the Director or Regional Forester. An adjacent landholder can acquire one parcel per year, with the option for more if parcels are under 160 acres, subject to approval for additional acreage. The Director or Regional Forester must provide public notice of available eligible Federal lands parcels for conveyance, even if they share a boundary with non-Federal land. The notice must confirm that the parcel meets the criteria for conveyance. The Director or Regional Forester must provide public notice of available eligible Federal lands parcels for conveyance, confirming that the parcel meets the criteria. If the parcel shares a boundary with non-Federal land, a negotiated sale will be carried out with the adjacent landholder. The Forester shall conduct a negotiated sale of eligible Federal lands with adjacent landholders. If multiple parcels owned by different landholders share a boundary, competitive bidding procedures will be used. Offers not meeting minimum consideration may be rejected, with an opportunity for appeal by the adjacent landholder. The Director or Regional Forester can reject offers that do not meet minimum requirements. The purchaser must agree to comply with local land use ordinances. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands must follow specified procedures. The Forester requires the purchaser to comply with local land use ordinances and zoning plans. The conveyance of Federal lands is done through a quitclaim deed. An appeals process is available if a request or offer is rejected by the Director or Regional Forester. The Director or Regional Forester provides an appeals process for reconsideration of rejected requests or offers regarding the conveyance of Federal lands, utilizing the expedited Forest Service appeals process available under section 322(d) of Public Law 102-381 (16 U.S.C. 1612 note). The Director or Regional Forester offers an expedited Forest Service appeals process for rejected requests or offers regarding the sale of Federal lands, requiring a cash payment equal to the fair market value of the parcel. The Director or Regional Forester requires a cash payment equal to the fair market value of an eligible Federal lands parcel being conveyed, established through an appraisal process. The Director or Regional Forester requires a cash payment equal to the fair market value of an eligible Federal lands parcel being conveyed, established through an appraisal process. If the appraisal is rejected, another appraisal must be conducted within 30 days. Proceeds from the conveyance are collected and deposited into a special fund established by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury shall establish a special fund for collecting and distributing funds from the conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels. Funds collected will be distributed annually to States where the Federal Government owns more than 33 percent of the land area, with 50 percent of the amount collected from a conveyance going to the State where the conveyance took place. The distribution of funds from the conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels is outlined in paragraph (4), with 50 percent going to the State where the conveyance took place and the remaining 50 percent distributed equally among other States. States receiving funds must agree to use them for purchasing additional eligible Federal lands parcels in line with land use management policies. Under this subsection, a State receiving funds must use them for purchasing additional eligible Federal lands parcels in line with land use management policies. The funds can also be used to comply with Federal requirements under the Endangered Species Act, Federal Water Pollution Control Act, or National Environmental Policy Act. The Director or Regional Forester must require the purchaser to pay for conveyance costs, including survey, appraisal, environmental documentation, and administrative costs. Any excess amount collected in advance must be refunded. The Director or Regional Forester must collect costs for conveyance, including appraisal, environmental documentation, and administrative costs. Any excess amount collected in advance must be refunded to the purchaser and credited back to the fund used for the conveyance. Amounts received as reimbursement for conveyance costs will be credited to the fund used for the conveyance and merged with existing amounts. These funds will be available for the same purposes and subject to the same conditions. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands should be completed within 18 months. Conveyances under this section are categorically excluded from exceptional resources. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands should be completed within 18 months and is categorically excluded from environmental assessments. This conveyance authority is in addition to existing sale authority under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act.
